chapters.title: 1. Basics
chapters.description: Core concepts, terminology, and inventory basics.

questions.question: Which pricing model pays per 1,000 impressions?
questions.correctAnswer: CPM
questions.explanation: CPM (Cost Per Mille) refers to the cost per 1,000 impressions. 'Mille' is Latin for one thousand.

questions.question: Difference between Ad Slot and Ad Space?
options: Slot is container, Space is creative area
Slot is video, Space is image
Space is container, Slot is content
questions.correctAnswer: Slot is container, Space is creative area
questions.explanation: The Ad Slot is the specific space reserved on a website (container), while Ad Space is the actual area inside it displaying the ad.

questions.question: What does 'CPA' stand for?
questions.correctAnswer: Cost Per Action
questions.explanation: Cost Per Action (CPA) is a pricing model where the advertiser pays only when a user completes a specific action like a purchase or sign-up.

questions.question: What is an 'Ad Network'?
options: Platform aggregating publisher inventory for advertisers
questions.correctAnswer: Platform aggregating publisher inventory for advertisers
questions.explanation: An ad network aggregates unsold publisher inventory and offers advertisers a consolidated pool of impressions, typically on a CPM basis.

questions.question: What is an 'Insertion Order'?
questions.correctAnswer: Agreement between advertiser and publisher
questions.explanation: An Insertion Order is a formal agreement between an advertiser and publisher that specifies the terms of an ad campaign.

questions.question: What is 'Fill Rate'?
options: Percentage of ad requests that are filled with an ad
Cost of filling an ad slot
questions.correctAnswer: Percentage of ad requests that are filled with an ad
questions.explanation: Fill Rate is a metric that calculates the percentage of ad requests that are successfully filled with an ad (Impressions / Ad Requests).

questions.question: What is 'eCPM'?
questions.correctAnswer: Effective Cost Per Mille
questions.explanation: eCPM (Effective Cost Per Mille) calculates the revenue generated per 1,000 impressions, regardless of the buying model (CPC, CPA, etc.).

questions.question: What is 'CTR'?
questions.correctAnswer: Click Through Rate
questions.explanation: CTR (Click Through Rate) is the ratio of users who click on a specific link to the number of total users who view an advertisement.

questions.question: What comprises the 'Ad Tech Stack'?
options: Collection of software used to manage digital advertising
questions.correctAnswer: Collection of software used to manage digital advertising
questions.explanation: The Ad Tech Stack refers to the collection of software and tools (DSPs, SSPs, DMPs, Ad Servers) used to manage, run, and optimize digital advertising campaigns.

questions.question: What does CPC stand for?
questions.correctAnswer: Cost Per Click
questions.explanation: CPC (Cost Per Click) is a pricing model where advertisers pay each time a user clicks on their ad.

questions.question: What is an 'Impression'?
options: When an ad is loaded and displayed
questions.correctAnswer: When an ad is loaded and displayed
questions.explanation: An impression occurs when an ad is fetched from its source and is counted each time the ad is displayed on a user's screen.

questions.question: What is 'Above the Fold'?
options: Ads at the top of the page visible without scrolling
questions.correctAnswer: Ads at the top of the page visible without scrolling
questions.explanation: Above the Fold refers to ad placements that are visible on screen without the user having to scroll down the page.

questions.question: What is 'Inventory' in ad tech?
questions.correctAnswer: Available ad space for purchase
questions.explanation: Inventory refers to the amount of ad space a publisher has available to sell to advertisers.

questions.question: What does ROI stand for?
questions.correctAnswer: Return on Investment
questions.explanation: ROI (Return on Investment) measures the profitability of an advertising campaign by comparing revenue generated to costs incurred.

questions.question: What is a 'Click'?
options: User interaction by clicking on an ad
questions.correctAnswer: User interaction by clicking on an ad
questions.explanation: A click is counted when a user actively clicks on an advertisement, typically redirecting them to the advertiser's website.

questions.question: What is 'CPI' in mobile advertising?
questions.correctAnswer: Cost Per Install
questions.explanation: CPI (Cost Per Install) is a pricing model used in mobile app advertising where advertisers pay when a user installs their app.

questions.question: What is 'Reach'?
options: Total number of unique users who see an ad
questions.correctAnswer: Total number of unique users who see an ad
questions.explanation: Reach measures the total number of different people or households exposed to an advertisement at least once during a campaign.

questions.question: What is 'Frequency'?
options: Average number of times a user sees an ad
questions.correctAnswer: Average number of times a user sees an ad
questions.explanation: Frequency is the average number of times an individual user is exposed to an advertisement during a campaign.

questions.question: What is 'Conversion'?
questions.correctAnswer: User completing a desired action
questions.explanation: A conversion occurs when a user completes a desired action after clicking on an ad, such as making a purchase or filling out a form.

questions.question: What is the difference between CPM and CPC?
options: CPM charges per thousand impressions, CPC charges per click
questions.correctAnswer: CPM charges per thousand impressions, CPC charges per click
questions.explanation: CPM is based on impressions (views), while CPC is based on actual user clicks on the advertisement.

questions.question: What is 'Ad Blocking'?
options: Software that prevents ads from displaying
questions.correctAnswer: Software that prevents ads from displaying
questions.explanation: Ad blocking refers to software that removes or alters advertising content on webpages, preventing ads from being displayed to users.

questions.question: What is 'Remnant Inventory'?
options: Unsold ad inventory sold at discounted rates
questions.correctAnswer: Unsold ad inventory sold at discounted rates
questions.explanation: Remnant inventory is leftover unsold ad space that publishers sell at lower prices, often through ad networks or exchanges.

questions.question: What does 'Direct Sales' mean in advertising?
options: Publisher selling inventory directly to advertisers
questions.correctAnswer: Publisher selling inventory directly to advertisers
questions.explanation: Direct sales is when a publisher's sales team sells ad inventory directly to advertisers without using automated platforms or intermediaries.

questions.question: What is a 'Campaign'?
questions.correctAnswer: Coordinated series of advertising activities
questions.explanation: A campaign is a coordinated series of advertisements and marketing efforts designed to achieve specific business objectives over a set period.

questions.question: What is 'Brand Awareness'?
options: Extent to which consumers recognize a brand
questions.correctAnswer: Extent to which consumers recognize a brand
questions.explanation: Brand awareness measures how familiar target audiences are with a brand and how well they can recall or recognize it.

questions.question: What is 'Performance Marketing'?
options: Marketing where payment is based on results
questions.correctAnswer: Marketing where payment is based on results
questions.explanation: Performance marketing is a comprehensive term referring to online marketing and advertising programs where advertisers pay only when a specific action occurs (click, sale, lead).

questions.question: What is 'CPL'?
questions.correctAnswer: Cost Per Lead
questions.explanation: CPL (Cost Per Lead) is a pricing model where advertisers pay for each qualified lead generated, such as a form submission or signup.

questions.question: What is an 'Ad Exchange'?
options: Digital marketplace for buying and selling ad inventory
questions.correctAnswer: Digital marketplace for buying and selling ad inventory
questions.explanation: An ad exchange is a technology platform that facilitates the buying and selling of media advertising inventory from multiple ad networks through real-time bidding.

questions.question: What is 'Yield'?
questions.correctAnswer: Revenue generated per impression
questions.explanation: Yield refers to the revenue a publisher generates from their advertising inventory, typically measured as revenue per thousand impressions.

questions.question: What is 'Guaranteed Inventory'?
options: Ad space reserved and sold at a fixed price
questions.correctAnswer: Ad space reserved and sold at a fixed price
questions.explanation: Guaranteed inventory (or reserved inventory) is ad space that a publisher commits to deliver to an advertiser at predetermined prices and dates.

questions.question: What does 'Revenue Share' mean?
options: Percentage of revenue split between parties
questions.correctAnswer: Percentage of revenue split between parties
questions.explanation: Revenue share is an agreement where partners split the revenue generated from advertising according to predetermined percentages.

questions.question: What is 'Floor Price'?
options: Lowest price a publisher will accept for inventory
questions.correctAnswer: Lowest price a publisher will accept for inventory
questions.explanation: Floor price is the minimum price a publisher is willing to accept for their ad inventory in an auction.

questions.question: What is 'eCPA'?
questions.correctAnswer: Effective Cost Per Action
questions.explanation: eCPA (Effective Cost Per Action) calculates the average cost to achieve a conversion, useful for comparing campaigns with different pricing models.

questions.question: What is 'Audience Extension'?
questions.correctAnswer: Reaching users beyond publisher's site
questions.explanation: Audience extension allows advertisers to reach their target audience across multiple websites beyond the original publisher's platform.

questions.question: What is 'Dayparting'?
options: Scheduling ads for specific times of day
questions.correctAnswer: Scheduling ads for specific times of day
questions.explanation: Dayparting is the practice of scheduling advertisements to run during specific hours or days when target audiences are most likely to be active.

questions.question: What is 'Geo-Targeting'?
options: Delivering ads based on user's geographic location
questions.correctAnswer: Delivering ads based on user's geographic location
questions.explanation: Geo-targeting allows advertisers to serve advertisements to users based on their geographic location, from country level down to specific zip codes.

questions.question: What is 'Contextual Advertising'?
questions.correctAnswer: Ads matched to page content
questions.explanation: Contextual advertising displays ads that are relevant to the content of the webpage, matching ad themes with page topics.

questions.question: What is 'ROAS'?
questions.correctAnswer: Return on Ad Spend
questions.explanation: ROAS (Return on Ad Spend) measures the revenue generated for every dollar spent on advertising, calculated as revenue divided by ad spend.

questions.question: What is a 'Landing Page'?
options: Page users arrive at after clicking an ad
questions.correctAnswer: Page users arrive at after clicking an ad
questions.explanation: A landing page is the specific webpage a user is directed to after clicking on an advertisement, designed to convert visitors into customers.

questions.question: What is 'Bounce Rate'?
options: Percentage of visitors who leave after viewing one page
questions.correctAnswer: Percentage of visitors who leave after viewing one page
questions.explanation: Bounce rate measures the percentage of visitors who navigate away from a site after viewing only one page, indicating low engagement.

questions.question: What are 'Display Ads'?
options: Visual banner ads with images or graphics
questions.correctAnswer: Visual banner ads with images or graphics
questions.explanation: Display ads are visual advertisements that appear on websites, typically in the form of banners, images, or rich media formats.

questions.question: What is 'Retargeting'?
options: Showing ads to users who previously visited your site
questions.correctAnswer: Showing ads to users who previously visited your site
questions.explanation: Retargeting (or remarketing) is a technique that serves ads to users who have previously visited a website or interacted with a brand.

questions.question: What is 'Attribution'?
options: Determining which touchpoints led to conversion
questions.correctAnswer: Determining which touchpoints led to conversion
questions.explanation: Attribution is the process of identifying which marketing touchpoints contributed to a user's conversion along their customer journey.

questions.question: What is an 'Ad Unit'?
options: Specific size and format of an ad placement
questions.correctAnswer: Specific size and format of an ad placement
questions.explanation: An ad unit refers to a specific ad placement with defined dimensions, format, and characteristics (e.g., 300x250 medium rectangle).

chapters.title: 2. Technology
chapters.description: DSPs, SSPs, and the tech stack components.

questions.question: What does DSP stand for?
questions.correctAnswer: Demand-Side Platform
questions.explanation: A Demand-Side Platform (DSP) allows media buyers to run advertising campaigns and buy inventory from various ad exchanges through a single interface.

questions.question: What is the primary function of an SSP?
options: To buy ad space for advertisers
To manage and sell publisher ad inventory
questions.correctAnswer: To manage and sell publisher ad inventory
questions.explanation: An SSP allows publishers to manage, sell, and optimize their ad inventory by connecting to ad exchanges and DSPs.

questions.question: Who uses an SSP?
questions.correctAnswer: Publishers
questions.explanation: Publishers use Supply-Side Platforms (SSPs) to manage and sell their ad inventory.

questions.question: What does IAB stand for?
questions.correctAnswer: Interactive Advertising Bureau
questions.explanation: The Interactive Advertising Bureau (IAB) is responsible for developing technical standards and promoting best practices in digital advertising.

questions.question: What does ATD stand for?
questions.correctAnswer: Agency Trading Desk
questions.explanation: An Agency Trading Desk (ATD) is a unit within an advertising agency that provides programmatic managed services to brands.

questions.question: What is an 'Ad Server'?
options: Technology to store and serve ads
questions.correctAnswer: Technology to store and serve ads
questions.explanation: An Ad Server is a web server dedicated to storing advertisements and delivering them to website visitors.

questions.question: What is a 'CMP'?
questions.correctAnswer: Consent Management Platform
questions.explanation: A Consent Management Platform (CMP) helps publishers collect and manage user consent for data processing (GDPR/CCPA compliance).

questions.question: Who typically uses a DSP?
questions.correctAnswer: Advertisers/Agencies
questions.explanation: DSPs are used by advertisers and agencies to buy ad inventory programmatically.

questions.question: What is a DMP?
questions.correctAnswer: Data Management Platform
questions.explanation: A DMP (Data Management Platform) is a centralized system for collecting, organizing, and activating audience data from various sources.

questions.question: What is the main difference between DSP and SSP?
options: DSP is for buyers, SSP is for sellers
questions.correctAnswer: DSP is for buyers, SSP is for sellers
questions.explanation: DSPs help advertisers buy inventory, while SSPs help publishers sell their inventory - they serve opposite sides of the marketplace.

questions.question: What does CDP stand for?
questions.correctAnswer: Customer Data Platform
questions.explanation: A CDP (Customer Data Platform) creates a persistent, unified customer database accessible to other marketing systems.

questions.question: What is an 'Ad Tag'?
options: Code snippet that calls an ad from the ad server
questions.correctAnswer: Code snippet that calls an ad from the ad server
questions.explanation: An ad tag is a piece of code placed on a webpage that requests and displays an advertisement from an ad server.

questions.question: What is 'Ad Trafficking'?
options: Process of setting up and managing ad campaigns
questions.correctAnswer: Process of setting up and managing ad campaigns
questions.explanation: Ad trafficking is the operational process of setting up, launching, and managing digital advertising campaigns in an ad server.

questions.question: What is a 'Pixel'?
questions.correctAnswer: 1x1 transparent image for tracking
questions.explanation: A tracking pixel is a tiny, invisible image embedded in webpages or emails to track user behavior and conversions.

questions.question: What does API stand for in ad tech?
questions.correctAnswer: Application Programming Interface
questions.explanation: An API allows different software applications to communicate and exchange data, commonly used for platform integrations in ad tech.

questions.question: What is 'Server-Side Ad Insertion' (SSAI)?
options: Stitching ads into video streams on the server
questions.correctAnswer: Stitching ads into video streams on the server
questions.explanation: SSAI integrates ads directly into the video stream on the server side, making them harder to block and providing a seamless viewing experience.

questions.question: What is a 'Cookie'?
options: Small data file stored on user's browser
questions.correctAnswer: Small data file stored on user's browser
questions.explanation: A cookie is a text file stored in a user's browser that tracks their behavior and preferences across websites for targeting and personalization.

questions.question: What is 'JavaScript'?
options: Programming language used for interactive web content
questions.correctAnswer: Programming language used for interactive web content
questions.explanation: JavaScript is a programming language used to create dynamic, interactive content on websites, including loading and displaying ads.

questions.question: What is an 'SDK'?
questions.correctAnswer: Software Development Kit
questions.explanation: An SDK is a collection of tools and code libraries that developers use to build applications, commonly used for integrating mobile ad platforms.

questions.question: What is 'VAST'?
questions.correctAnswer: Video Ad Serving Template
questions.explanation: VAST is an IAB standard that provides a uniform way for video players to interface with ad servers for video advertising.

questions.question: What is 'VPAID'?
questions.correctAnswer: Video Player Ad Interface Definition
questions.explanation: VPAID is an IAB standard that enables interactive in-stream video ads and provides a common interface for video players and ad units.

questions.question: What is a 'Third-Party Ad Server'?
options: Independent ad server used by advertisers
questions.correctAnswer: Independent ad server used by advertisers
questions.explanation: A third-party ad server is controlled by the advertiser or agency and provides independent tracking and verification, separate from the publisher's server.

questions.question: What is 'Prebid'?
questions.correctAnswer: Open-source header bidding solution
questions.explanation: Prebid.js is an open-source header bidding wrapper that allows publishers to simultaneously request bids from multiple demand sources.

questions.question: What is 'OpenRTB'?
questions.correctAnswer: Real-time bidding standard by IAB
questions.explanation: OpenRTB is an IAB standard communication protocol for real-time bidding auctions, enabling interoperability between buyers and sellers.

questions.question: What is 'Ad Fraud Detection'?
options: Technology to identify invalid traffic and bot activity
questions.correctAnswer: Technology to identify invalid traffic and bot activity
questions.explanation: Ad fraud detection uses algorithms and machine learning to identify and filter out fraudulent impressions, clicks, and conversions caused by bots or invalid traffic.

questions.question: What is 'IVT'?
questions.correctAnswer: Invalid Traffic
questions.explanation: IVT (Invalid Traffic) refers to impressions, clicks, or conversions generated by bots, scrapers, or other non-human sources that should be filtered out.

questions.question: What is a 'Wrapper Tag'?
options: Container tag that holds multiple ad tags
questions.correctAnswer: Container tag that holds multiple ad tags
questions.explanation: A wrapper tag is a container that manages and coordinates multiple ad tags, commonly used in header bidding implementations.

questions.question: What is 'Ad Stitching'?
options: Inserting ads seamlessly into video content
questions.correctAnswer: Inserting ads seamlessly into video content
questions.explanation: Ad stitching combines video content and advertisements into a single stream, making the viewing experience smoother and ads harder to skip.

questions.question: What does 'OM SDK' stand for?
questions.correctAnswer: Open Measurement Software Development Kit
questions.explanation: OM SDK is an IAB standard that enables third-party viewability and verification measurement in mobile apps without multiple SDKs.

questions.question: What is 'Identity Resolution'?
options: Matching user identifiers across devices and platforms
questions.correctAnswer: Matching user identifiers across devices and platforms
questions.explanation: Identity resolution links different identifiers (cookies, device IDs, emails) to create a unified view of an individual user across touchpoints.

questions.question: What is a 'Lookalike Audience'?
options: New users similar to existing customers
questions.correctAnswer: New users similar to existing customers
questions.explanation: A lookalike audience is created by finding new users who share similar characteristics and behaviors with a brand's existing high-value customers.

questions.question: What is 'Cross-Device Tracking'?
questions.correctAnswer: Following users across different devices
questions.explanation: Cross-device tracking identifies and tracks users as they switch between smartphones, tablets, laptops, and other connected devices.

questions.question: What is an 'Attribution Model'?
options: Framework for assigning conversion credit to touchpoints
questions.correctAnswer: Framework for assigning conversion credit to touchpoints
questions.explanation: An attribution model is a set of rules that determines how credit for conversions is assigned to various marketing touchpoints in the customer journey.

questions.question: What is 'First-Party Data'?
options: Data collected directly from your own customers
questions.correctAnswer: Data collected directly from your own customers
questions.explanation: First-party data is information a company collects directly from its own customers through interactions, purchases, and website behavior.

questions.question: What is 'Third-Party Data'?
questions.correctAnswer: Data purchased from external providers
questions.explanation: Third-party data is collected by entities that don't have a direct relationship with users, then aggregated and sold to advertisers for targeting.

questions.question: What is 'Tag Management System' (TMS)?
options: Platform for managing marketing tags on a website
questions.correctAnswer: Platform for managing marketing tags on a website
questions.explanation: A TMS (e.g., Google Tag Manager) allows marketers to easily add, update, and manage tracking tags and scripts on their website without developer help.

questions.question: What is 'Audience Segmentation'?
options: Dividing users into groups based on characteristics
questions.correctAnswer: Dividing users into groups based on characteristics
questions.explanation: Audience segmentation divides a target market into distinct groups based on demographics, behaviors, interests, or other criteria for personalized messaging.

questions.question: What is a 'Bidder'?
questions.correctAnswer: Auction participant submitting bid responses
questions.explanation: A bidder is a demand-side platform or ad network that participates in real-time bidding auctions by submitting bids for ad impressions.

chapters.title: 3. Advertising Mediums
chapters.description: Channels, Formats, Video, Native, and DOOH.

questions.question: What is a 'Creative'?
questions.correctAnswer: The actual ad file (image/video/audio)
questions.explanation: A creative is the file that contains the actual advertisement a user sees or hears.

questions.question: What is 'Native Advertising'?
questions.correctAnswer: Ads that blend with content
questions.explanation: Native ads are designed to blend seamlessly with surrounding content by matching the design, format, and behavior of the platform.

questions.question: What does DOOH stand for?
questions.correctAnswer: Digital-Out-Of-Home
questions.explanation: DOOH refers to Digital-Out-Of-Home advertising, such as digital billboards and screens in public spaces.

questions.question: What does CTV stand for?
questions.correctAnswer: Connected TV
questions.explanation: CTV stands for Connected TV, referring to television sets that can connect to the internet and stream content.

questions.question: What does MAID stand for?
questions.correctAnswer: Mobile Advertising ID
questions.explanation: MAID stands for Mobile Advertising ID (or Mobile Device ID), a unique identifier assigned to mobile devices for advertising purposes.

questions.question: What is 'OTT'?
questions.correctAnswer: Over-The-Top
questions.explanation: OTT (Over-The-Top) refers to content providers that distribute streaming media as a standalone product directly to viewers over the internet.

questions.question: Which format is considered 'Rich Media'?
questions.correctAnswer: Interactive HTML5/Video
questions.explanation: Rich Media ads include advanced features like video, audio, or other elements that encourage viewers to interact and engage with the content.

questions.question: What is 'In-Stream Video'?
questions.correctAnswer: Video played within video content (pre/mid/post-roll)
questions.explanation: In-Stream video ads play before, during, or after streaming video content (like a TV commercial within a YouTube video).

questions.question: What is 'Out-Stream Video'?
options: Video ads that play outside of video content
questions.correctAnswer: Video ads that play outside of video content
questions.explanation: Out-Stream video ads (also called in-read or in-feed) play within text content, social feeds, or between paragraphs, not within video players.

questions.question: What is a 'Pre-Roll Ad'?
options: Video ad that plays before main content
questions.correctAnswer: Video ad that plays before main content
questions.explanation: Pre-roll ads are video advertisements that play before the desired video content starts, similar to TV commercials before a show.

questions.question: What is a 'Mid-Roll Ad'?
options: Video ad that plays during content breaks
questions.correctAnswer: Video ad that plays during content breaks
questions.explanation: Mid-roll ads are video advertisements that play in the middle of video content, typically at natural break points in longer videos.

questions.question: What is a 'Post-Roll Ad'?
options: Video ad that plays after content ends
questions.correctAnswer: Video ad that plays after content ends
questions.explanation: Post-roll ads are video advertisements that play after the main video content has finished, though they typically have lower completion rates.

questions.question: What is an 'Interstitial Ad'?
questions.correctAnswer: Full-screen ad between content transitions
questions.explanation: Interstitial ads are full-screen advertisements that appear at natural transition points in an app or between web pages.

questions.question: What is a 'Rewarded Video Ad'?
options: Video ad offering incentive for watching
questions.correctAnswer: Video ad offering incentive for watching
questions.explanation: Rewarded video ads offer users an incentive (like in-game currency or premium content) in exchange for watching a complete video advertisement.

questions.question: What is 'Programmatic DOOH'?
options: Automated buying of digital out-of-home ads
questions.correctAnswer: Automated buying of digital out-of-home ads
questions.explanation: Programmatic DOOH uses automated technology to buy and display digital outdoor advertising on billboards and screens in real-time.

questions.question: What is 'Expandable Ad'?
options: Ad that enlarges when interacted with
questions.correctAnswer: Ad that enlarges when interacted with
questions.explanation: An expandable ad starts at a standard size but expands to a larger format when a user interacts with it (hover or click).

questions.question: What is a 'Sticky Ad'?
options: Ad that remains visible while scrolling
questions.correctAnswer: Ad that remains visible while scrolling
questions.explanation: A sticky ad (or fixed ad) remains in a fixed position on screen as users scroll through content, maintaining visibility.

questions.question: What is 'Companion Banner'?
options: Display ad shown alongside video content
questions.correctAnswer: Display ad shown alongside video content
questions.explanation: A companion banner is a display ad that appears next to or around a video player while the video ad plays, providing additional brand exposure.

questions.question: What is 'Shoppable Video'?
questions.correctAnswer: Video with clickable product links
questions.explanation: Shoppable video allows viewers to click on products featured in the video to learn more or make purchases directly without leaving the video.

questions.question: What is 'Audio Advertising'?
options: Ads delivered through audio content like podcasts
questions.correctAnswer: Ads delivered through audio content like podcasts
questions.explanation: Audio advertising includes ads delivered through podcasts, music streaming services, and digital radio, without video components.

questions.question: What is 'Skinning' in web advertising?
questions.correctAnswer: Background takeover surrounding content
questions.explanation: Skinning (or page skin) is when an advertiser's branding wraps around and frames the entire webpage, creating high-impact brand visibility.

questions.question: What is an 'In-App Ad'?
questions.correctAnswer: Advertisement displayed within mobile applications
questions.explanation: In-app ads are advertisements that appear within mobile applications, including banners, interstitials, native ads, and rewarded videos.

questions.question: What is 'Mobile Web' advertising?
options: Ads on mobile websites accessed via browsers
questions.correctAnswer: Ads on mobile websites accessed via browsers
questions.explanation: Mobile web advertising refers to ads displayed on websites accessed through mobile device browsers, as opposed to in-app advertising.

questions.question: What is 'Playable Ad'?
options: Interactive ad demo of app or game
questions.correctAnswer: Interactive ad demo of app or game
questions.explanation: Playable ads allow users to try a mini-version or demo of a mobile game or app before downloading, increasing engagement and quality installs.

questions.question: What is 'Podcast Advertising'?
questions.correctAnswer: Audio ads in podcast episodes
questions.explanation: Podcast advertising includes host-read ads, pre-recorded spots, or programmatic audio ads inserted into podcast episodes.

questions.question: What is 'Social Media Advertising'?
options: Ads on social platforms like Facebook, Instagram, Twitter
questions.correctAnswer: Ads on social platforms like Facebook, Instagram, Twitter
questions.explanation: Social media advertising encompasses paid advertisements on social networking platforms, leveraging user data for highly targeted campaigns.

questions.question: What is 'Influencer Marketing'?
options: Partnering with social media influencers for promotion
questions.correctAnswer: Partnering with social media influencers for promotion
questions.explanation: Influencer marketing involves collaborating with social media personalities who promote products to their engaged follower base.

questions.question: What is 'Addressable TV'?
options: Delivering different ads to different households on same program
questions.correctAnswer: Delivering different ads to different households on same program
questions.explanation: Addressable TV allows advertisers to show different ads to different households watching the same program, based on household data and preferences.

questions.question: What is a 'Takeover Ad'?
options: Exclusive homepage branding for a period
questions.correctAnswer: Exclusive homepage branding for a period
questions.explanation: A takeover (or roadblock) is when an advertiser exclusively owns all ad placements on a site or page for a specific time period.

questions.question: What is 'Voice-Activated Advertising'?
options: Ads on smart speakers and voice assistants
questions.correctAnswer: Ads on smart speakers and voice assistants
questions.explanation: Voice-activated advertising delivers audio ads through smart speakers like Alexa or Google Home and voice assistant platforms.

questions.question: Which audio ad format is read live by the podcast host?
questions.correctAnswer: Host-Read Ad
questions.explanation: Host-read ads are delivered by the podcast host themselves, often feeling more authentic and integrated into the show's content.

questions.question: What distinguishes 'Dynamic Creative' from standard display ads?
options: Automatically changing elements based on user data
questions.correctAnswer: Automatically changing elements based on user data
questions.explanation: Dynamic creatives automatically adapt elements (copy, images, offers) in real-time based on viewer data like location, weather, or product history.

questions.question: In DOOH, what is 'dwell time'?
options: Length of time an ad stays on screen
Time a viewer spends in the vicinity of the screen
questions.correctAnswer: Time a viewer spends in the vicinity of the screen
questions.explanation: Dwell time in DOOH refers to the duration a person remains in the viewable area of a digital screen, impacting the opportunity to see ads.

questions.question: What is a 'Push Notification Ad'?
options: Ad delivered to a user's device notification tray
questions.correctAnswer: Ad delivered to a user's device notification tray
questions.explanation: Push notification ads appear as system alerts on a user's mobile or desktop device, resembling native app notifications.

questions.question: What is 'Interactive Video'?
options: Video allowing user inputs (clicks, choices, forms) within the player
questions.correctAnswer: Video allowing user inputs (clicks, choices, forms) within the player
questions.explanation: Interactive video allows viewers to engage directly with the video content through hotspots, quizzes, forms, or branching storylines.

questions.question: What is 'ACR' in Connected TV?
questions.correctAnswer: Automatic Content Recognition
questions.explanation: ACR technology identifies content playing on a smart TV (shows, ads) by analyzing audio or video fingerprints, enabling targeting.

questions.question: What is a 'Cinema Graph' ad?
options: Static image with subtle motion loop
questions.correctAnswer: Static image with subtle motion loop
questions.explanation: A cinemagraph is a still photograph in which a minor and repeated movement occurs to catch the eye, blending photo and video properties.

questions.question: What is 'Haptic Ads'?
options: Ads that use device vibration/tactile feedback
questions.correctAnswer: Ads that use device vibration/tactile feedback
questions.explanation: Haptic ads use the vibration motor in mobile devices to provide tactile feedback (vibrations) synchronized with visual or audio ad elements.

questions.question: What is a 'Masthead' ad?
options: Premium placement at the top of a homepage (e.g., YouTube)
questions.correctAnswer: Premium placement at the top of a homepage (e.g., YouTube)
questions.explanation: A Masthead is a prime, highly visible ad unit placed at the very top of a homepage, famously used on YouTube for high-impact campaigns.

questions.question: What defines 'User Generated Content' (UGC) ads?
options: Ads creating using content made by consumers
questions.correctAnswer: Ads creating using content made by consumers
questions.explanation: UGC ads leverage photos, videos, or reviews created by actual customers, often feeling more authentic and trustworthy than polished brand assets.

questions.question: What is 'In-Game Advertising'?
options: Ads integrated directly into video game environments
questions.correctAnswer: Ads integrated directly into video game environments
questions.explanation: In-game advertising places ads realistically within the 3D game world, such as billboards in a racing game or jerseys in a sports game.

questions.question: What is a 'Carousel Ad'?
options: Ad format with multiple swipable cards/images
questions.correctAnswer: Ad format with multiple swipable cards/images
questions.explanation: Carousel ads allow advertisers to showcase multiple images or products in a single ad unit that users can swipe or click through horizontally.

questions.question: What is 'Vertical Video'?
options: Video optimized for mobile portrait mode (9:16)
questions.correctAnswer: Video optimized for mobile portrait mode (9:16)
questions.explanation: Vertical video is created in a 9:16 aspect ratio to fill the entire screen on mobile devices without requiring the user to rotate their phone.

questions.question: What is 'Listen-Through Rate' (LTR)?
options: Percentage of an audio ad listened to completion
questions.correctAnswer: Percentage of an audio ad listened to completion
questions.explanation: LTR measures the percentage of an audio advertisement that was played through to the end, similar to completion rate in video.

questions.question: What is '360-Degree Video Ad'?
questions.correctAnswer: Video where viewer controls angle/perspective
questions.explanation: 360-degree video ads allow viewers to look around in every direction within the video player, creating an immersive experience.

questions.question: What is 'Augmented Reality (AR) Ad'?
options: Ad overlaying digital elements on the real world via camera
questions.correctAnswer: Ad overlaying digital elements on the real world via camera
questions.explanation: AR ads allow users to visualize products in their real environment (e.g., trying on sunglasses) using their device's camera.

questions.question: What is 'Sequential Messaging'?
options: Showing a series of ads in a specific order to a user
questions.correctAnswer: Showing a series of ads in a specific order to a user
questions.explanation: Sequential messaging tells a story by showing a user a specific sequence of ads (Part 1, then Part 2, then Part 3) over time.

questions.question: What is 'Dynamic Overlay'?
options: Adding personalized text/graphics over existing video/image
questions.correctAnswer: Adding personalized text/graphics over existing video/image
questions.explanation: Dynamic overlays add real-time, personalized information (like local store address or pricing) on top of a base video or image creative.

questions.question: What is 'Sponsoring' a section?
options: Paying to have 'Presented by' branding on specific content property
questions.correctAnswer: Paying to have 'Presented by' branding on specific content property
questions.explanation: Sponsorship involves an advertiser paying for exclusive association with specific content or a site section, often indicated by 'Presented By' branding.

questions.question: What is 'Interstitial' on Mobile?
options: Full screen ad appearing between app screens
questions.correctAnswer: Full screen ad appearing between app screens
questions.explanation: Mobile interstitials are full-screen ads that cover the interface of a host app, typically displayed at natural transition points like between game levels.

questions.question: What does 'Header Bidding' enable?
options: Simultaneous demand competition before ad server
questions.correctAnswer: Simultaneous demand competition before ad server
questions.explanation: Header bidding allows publishers to offer inventory to multiple ad exchanges simultaneously before making calls to their ad servers.

questions.question: What is 'Ad Verification'?
options: Ensuring ads appear as intended and detecting fraud
questions.correctAnswer: Ensuring ads appear as intended and detecting fraud
questions.explanation: Ad verification services provide information about where ads appeared, whether they were viewable, and if fraudulent traffic was detected.

questions.question: What is the 'Waterfall' model?
options: Sequential ad calling usually by priority
questions.correctAnswer: Sequential ad calling usually by priority
questions.explanation: The Waterfall (or daisy chain) is a technique where the publisher's ad server calls ad sources one by one in a pre-defined priority order.

questions.question: Who hosts the First-Party Ad Server?
questions.correctAnswer: The Publisher
questions.explanation: A First-Party Ad Server is used by the publisher to manage their inventory and serve ads to their own website.

questions.question: What is 'Passback'?
options: Returning an impression to another system if unfilled
questions.correctAnswer: Returning an impression to another system if unfilled
questions.explanation: A passback (or default tag) sends the ad opportunity back to another system (usually lower in the waterfall) when the current partner cannot fill the impression.

questions.question: What is 'RTB'?
questions.correctAnswer: Real-Time Bidding
questions.explanation: RTB (Real-Time Bidding) is the process of buying and selling ad impressions in real-time auctions that occur in milliseconds as a webpage loads.

questions.question: What is 'Prebid Header Bidding'?
questions.correctAnswer: Wrapper solution for simultaneous bidding
questions.explanation: Prebid is an open-source header bidding wrapper that enables publishers to request bids from multiple demand partners simultaneously in the browser.

questions.question: What is 'Viewability'?
options: Percentage of ad that was actually visible to users
questions.correctAnswer: Percentage of ad that was actually visible to users
questions.explanation: Viewability measures whether an ad had the opportunity to be seen by a user, with IAB standards defining viewable impressions.

questions.question: What is the MRC Viewability Standard?
options: 100% of ad visible for any time
50% of ad visible for at least 1 second (display) or 2 seconds (video)
questions.correctAnswer: 50% of ad visible for at least 1 second (display) or 2 seconds (video)
questions.explanation: The Media Rating Council (MRC) standard defines a viewable impression as 50% of pixels visible for 1+ second (display) or 2+ seconds (video).

questions.question: What is 'Brand Safety'?
options: Ensuring ads don't appear next to inappropriate content
questions.correctAnswer: Ensuring ads don't appear next to inappropriate content
questions.explanation: Brand safety measures ensure advertisements don't appear alongside content that could damage brand reputation, like hate speech or violent content.

questions.question: What is 'Ad Fraud'?
questions.correctAnswer: Generating false impressions/clicks for profit
questions.explanation: Ad fraud involves deliberately generating fake impressions, clicks, or conversions through bots or other deceptive methods to steal advertising budgets.

questions.question: What is a 'Bot'?
options: Automated software that mimics user behavior
questions.correctAnswer: Automated software that mimics user behavior
questions.explanation: Bots are automated programs that generate fake traffic, impressions, and clicks, leading to ad fraud and wasted advertising spend.

questions.question: What is 'Click Fraud'?
questions.correctAnswer: Artificially inflating click numbers
questions.explanation: Click fraud is the deliberate clicking on ads (by humans or bots) to generate illegitimate charges for advertisers or revenue for publishers.

questions.question: What is 'Ad Stacking'?
options: Layering multiple ads on top of each other
questions.correctAnswer: Layering multiple ads on top of each other
questions.explanation: Ad stacking is a fraud technique where multiple ads are placed on top of each other in a single ad placement, with only the top ad visible.

questions.question: What is 'Pixel Stuffing'?
options: Serving ads in tiny 1x1 pixel sizes
questions.correctAnswer: Serving ads in tiny 1x1 pixel sizes
questions.explanation: Pixel stuffing is a fraud technique where ads are served in impossibly small sizes (like 1x1 pixels) making them invisible but still counting impressions.

questions.question: What is 'Domain Spoofing'?
options: Misrepresenting the domain where ads are served
questions.correctAnswer: Misrepresenting the domain where ads are served
questions.explanation: Domain spoofing is when fraudsters misrepresent low-quality inventory as coming from premium publishers to command higher prices.

questions.question: What is 'Ads.txt'?
options: Text file listing authorized digital sellers
questions.correctAnswer: Text file listing authorized digital sellers
questions.explanation: Ads.txt is an IAB initiative where publishers post a text file listing all companies authorized to sell their inventory, fighting domain spoofing.

questions.question: What is 'App-ads.txt'?
options: Authorized sellers list for mobile app inventory
questions.correctAnswer: Authorized sellers list for mobile app inventory
questions.explanation: App-ads.txt extends the ads.txt standard to mobile apps, allowing app developers to list authorized sellers of their in-app inventory.

questions.question: What is a 'Private Marketplace' (PMP)?
questions.correctAnswer: Invite-only programmatic auction
questions.explanation: A Private Marketplace is an invitation-only RTB auction where publishers offer premium inventory to select advertisers at negotiated floor prices.

questions.question: What is a 'Programmatic Guaranteed' deal?
options: Automated direct deal with fixed price and volume
questions.correctAnswer: Automated direct deal with fixed price and volume
questions.explanation: Programmatic Guaranteed (or Programmatic Direct) is an automated one-to-one deal between publisher and advertiser with guaranteed impressions at a fixed CPM.

questions.question: What is 'Preferred Deal'?
options: First look at inventory before open auction
questions.correctAnswer: First look at inventory before open auction
questions.explanation: A Preferred Deal (or First Look) gives select buyers the opportunity to bid on inventory at a fixed price before it goes to the open auction.

questions.question: What is 'Open Auction'?
options: Available to all buyers in real-time bidding
questions.correctAnswer: Available to all buyers in real-time bidding
questions.explanation: Open Auction is the most common programmatic buying method where inventory is available to all participating buyers through real-time bidding.

questions.question: What is 'Ad Quality'?
options: Ensuring ads meet technical and content standards
questions.correctAnswer: Ensuring ads meet technical and content standards
questions.explanation: Ad quality refers to processes that ensure advertisements meet technical specifications, don't contain malware, and comply with content policies.

questions.question: What is 'Latency' in ad serving?
options: Delay between ad request and delivery
questions.correctAnswer: Delay between ad request and delivery
questions.explanation: Latency is the time delay between when an ad is requested and when it's displayed, which can impact user experience and viewability.

questions.question: What is 'Ad Refresh'?
options: Automatically loading new ads without page reload
questions.correctAnswer: Automatically loading new ads without page reload
questions.explanation: Ad refresh (or auto-refresh) automatically reloads new advertisements in the same placement after a set time interval without requiring a page reload.

questions.question: What is a 'Daisy Chain' in ad serving?
questions.correctAnswer: Another term for Waterfall model
questions.explanation: Daisy Chain is another term for the Waterfall model, describing the sequential passing of ad requests from one network to the next.

questions.question: What is an 'Ad Call'?
options: Request sent from browser to ad server for an ad
questions.correctAnswer: Request sent from browser to ad server for an ad
questions.explanation: An ad call is the HTTP request sent from the user's browser (via the ad tag) to the ad server to fetch an advertisement to display.

questions.question: What is 'Creative Hosting'?
options: Storing the actual image/video files on a server (CDN)
questions.correctAnswer: Storing the actual image/video files on a server (CDN)
questions.explanation: Creative hosting involves storing the physical ad assets (images, videos, HTML5) on a Content Delivery Network (CDN) for fast delivery to users.

questions.question: What is a 'Macro' in an ad tag?
options: Placeholder replaced by dynamic value by ad server
questions.correctAnswer: Placeholder replaced by dynamic value by ad server
questions.explanation: A macro (e.g., %%CACHEBUSTER%%) is a placeholder in an ad tag that the ad server replaces with a real value (like a timestamp or ID) when serving the ad.

questions.question: What is a 'Cachebuster'?
options: Random number added to URL to prevent browser caching
questions.correctAnswer: Random number added to URL to prevent browser caching
questions.explanation: A cachebuster is a unique string (usually a random number or timestamp) added to ad requests to ensure the browser fetches a fresh ad instead of a cached version.

questions.question: What is 'Verification Tag'?
options: Code from 3rd party to measure viewability/fraud
questions.correctAnswer: Code from 3rd party to measure viewability/fraud
questions.explanation: Verification tags (from vendors like IAS, DV) are wrapped around or included with the ad creative to independently measure viewability, brand safety, and fraud.

questions.question: What is 'Discrepancy' in ad tech?
options: Difference in numbers reported by two different systems
questions.correctAnswer: Difference in numbers reported by two different systems
questions.explanation: Discrepancy refers to the variance in counted impressions or clicks between two systems (e.g., Publisher Ad Server vs Advertiser DSP), usually <10% is acceptable.

questions.question: What is 'Geofencing'?
options: Triggering ads when devices enter a specific GPS radius
questions.correctAnswer: Triggering ads when devices enter a specific GPS radius
questions.explanation: Geofencing uses GPS technology to create a virtual geographic boundary, enabling software to trigger ads when a mobile device enters or leaves a particular area.

questions.question: What is 'Video Completion Rate' (VCR)?
options: Percentage of video ads played to the end
questions.correctAnswer: Percentage of video ads played to the end
questions.explanation: VCR measures the percentage of viewable video impressions were played through to completion (100%), a key metric for branding campaigns.

questions.question: What is 'MRAID'?
options: Mobile Rich Media Ad Interface Definitions
questions.correctAnswer: Mobile Rich Media Ad Interface Definitions
questions.explanation: MRAID is an IAB API standard for mobile rich media ads that allows them to interact with the mobile app (e.g., expand, resize, access calendar).

questions.question: What is 'SafeFrame'?
options: Secure iframe allowing ad interaction without site access
questions.correctAnswer: Secure iframe allowing ad interaction without site access
questions.explanation: SafeFrame is an IAB standard that provides a secure container (iframe) for ads, allowing rich interaction without giving the ad code full access to the publisher's page data.

questions.question: What is 'Fill Rate'?
options: Percentage of ad requests that result in a served ad
questions.correctAnswer: Percentage of ad requests that result in a served ad
questions.explanation: Fill Rate is the ratio of ad impressions successfully served divided by the total number of ad requests received, expressed as a percentage.

questions.question: What is 'eCPM'?
questions.correctAnswer: Effective Cost Per Mille
questions.explanation: eCPM calculates the effective revenue earned per 1,000 impressions, allowing comparison of revenue across different pricing models (CPC, CPA, CPM).

questions.question: What is 'Share of Voice' (SOV)?
options: Percentage of total advertising exposure compared to competitors
questions.correctAnswer: Percentage of total advertising exposure compared to competitors
questions.explanation: Share of Voice represents the percentage of the total advertising inventory or market visibility that a specific brand owns compared to competitors.

questions.question: What is 'Ad Blocker'?
options: Software that prevents ads from displaying
questions.correctAnswer: Software that prevents ads from displaying
questions.explanation: Ad blockers are software or browser extensions that identify and prevent advertising content from loading on webpages.

questions.question: What is 'Frequency Cap' level options?
options: Campaign, Line Item, Creative, or Advertiser level
questions.correctAnswer: Campaign, Line Item, Creative, or Advertiser level
questions.explanation: Frequency caps can typically be set at multiple levels: per campaign, per specific line item, per creative, or across an entire advertiser's portfolio.

questions.question: What is 'Default Impression'?
options: Ad shown when no other paid ad is available
questions.correctAnswer: Ad shown when no other paid ad is available
questions.explanation: A default impression (or house ad/blank) is served when the ad server cannot find a paying ad that matches the targeting criteria.

questions.question: What is 'Roadblock'?
options: Owning 100% of ad slots on a page simultaneously
questions.correctAnswer: Owning 100% of ad slots on a page simultaneously
questions.explanation: A Roadblock is a takeover where an advertiser buys all the ad placements on a single page at the same time to ensure exclusive visibility.

questions.question: What is 'Flight Dates'?
options: Start and end dates of an ad campaign
questions.correctAnswer: Start and end dates of an ad campaign
questions.explanation: Flight dates refer to the specific date range during which an advertising campaign is active and running.

questions.question: What is 'Creative Rotation'?
options: Strategy for cycling through different ad versions
questions.correctAnswer: Strategy for cycling through different ad versions
questions.explanation: Creative rotation determines the order or rules (e.g., even, weighted, optimized) for displaying different creative versions within a single ad placement.

questions.question: What is 'Conversion Window'?
options: Period after click/view where conversion is attributed
questions.correctAnswer: Period after click/view where conversion is attributed
questions.explanation: A conversion window is the specific timeframe after an ad interaction (click or view) during which a subsequent conversion will be credited to that ad.

questions.question: What is 'Click-Through Conversion'?
options: Conversion happening after user clicked an ad
questions.correctAnswer: Conversion happening after user clicked an ad
questions.explanation: A click-through conversion is counted when a user directly clicks on an ad and then completes a conversion action within the lookback window.

questions.question: What is 'View-Through Conversion'?
options: Conversion after seeing ad but not clicking
questions.correctAnswer: Conversion after seeing ad but not clicking
questions.explanation: A view-through conversion is credited when a user sees an ad, does not click it, but later returns to the site to convert within the lookback window.

questions.question: What is 'Exclusion Targeting'?
options: Preventing ads from showing to specific criteria
questions.correctAnswer: Preventing ads from showing to specific criteria
questions.explanation: Exclusion targeting (or negative targeting) ensures ads are NOT shown to specific audiences, contexts, or geographies (e.g., excluding current customers).

questions.question: What is 'Inventory Quality'?
questions.correctAnswer: Value/legitimacy of publisher ad space
questions.explanation: Inventory quality assesses the caliber of the publisher's content, audience, and ad placements, ensuring they are fraud-free, viewable, and brand-safe.

questions.question: What is a 'Walled Garden'?
questions.correctAnswer: Closed ecosystem (Google/Meta)
questions.explanation: A Walled Garden refers to a closed ecosystem where a platform controls access to its users, data, and inventory (e.g., Google, Apple, Meta, Amazon).

questions.question: What is 'Contextual Targeting'?
questions.correctAnswer: Targeting based on page content/keywords
questions.explanation: Contextual targeting displays ads based on the content of the website page (e.g., shoe ads on a running blog) rather than user data.

questions.question: What is 'Audience Segmentation'?
options: Dividing users into groups based on characteristics
questions.correctAnswer: Dividing users into groups based on characteristics
questions.explanation: Audience segmentation is the process of dividing users into specific groups based on shared characteristics, behaviors, or demographics.

questions.question: What is a 'Look-alike Model'?
options: Targeting users similar to existing customers
questions.correctAnswer: Targeting users similar to existing customers
questions.explanation: Look-alike modeling uses data to find new audiences who share characteristics with your best existing customers.

questions.question: What is 'Brand Safety'?
options: Ensuring ads don't appear near inappropriate content
questions.correctAnswer: Ensuring ads don't appear near inappropriate content
questions.explanation: Brand safety practices ensure that ads do not appear on web pages with content that is inappropriate or illegal.

questions.question: What does GAMA stand for?
questions.correctAnswer: Google, Apple, Meta, Amazon
questions.explanation: GAMA refers to Google, Apple, Meta, and Amazon, considered among the most prominent walled gardens in the AdTech ecosystem.

questions.question: What is 'Geotargeting'?
options: Targeting based on time of day
questions.correctAnswer: Targeting based on user location
questions.explanation: Geotargeting involves delivering content to a user based on their geographic location, such as country, city, or zip code.

questions.question: What is 'Retargeting'?
options: Showing ads to users who previously visited your site
questions.correctAnswer: Showing ads to users who previously visited your site
questions.explanation: Retargeting (or Remarketing) is a strategy to serve ads to users who have already visited your website or interacted with your brand.

questions.question: What is 'Dayparting'?
options: Scheduling ads to run at specific times of day
questions.correctAnswer: Scheduling ads to run at specific times of day
questions.explanation: Dayparting involves scheduling advertising campaigns to run only during specific hours of the day or days of the week.

questions.question: What is the primary benefit of Lookalike Modeling?
options: Finding new users similar to your best customers
Retargeting users who clicked an ad
questions.correctAnswer: Finding new users similar to your best customers
questions.explanation: Lookalike modeling uses algorithmic analysis to find new audiences that share characteristics with a seed audience (e.g., high-value customers).

questions.question: What is the primary benefit of Lookalike Modeling?
options: Finding new users similar to your best customers
Retargeting users who clicked an ad
questions.correctAnswer: Finding new users similar to your best customers
questions.explanation: Lookalike modeling uses algorithmic analysis to find new audiences that share characteristics with a seed audience (e.g., high-value customers).

questions.question: What is a 'Viewable Impression'?
questions.correctAnswer: Ad seen by a user
questions.explanation: A viewable impression is a metric used to ensure the ad was contained in the viewable space of the browser window and seen by a real user.

questions.question: What is a 'Conversion'?
questions.correctAnswer: Completing a desired action
questions.explanation: A conversion occurs when a user completes a specific goal defined by the advertiser, such as making a purchase or signing up.

questions.question: What is a 'Landing Page'?
options: Page where users arrive after clicking an ad
questions.correctAnswer: Page where users arrive after clicking an ad
questions.explanation: A landing page is a web page where users 'land' after clicking an ad or link, designed specifically to drive conversions.

questions.question: What is 'Viewability'?
options: Whether an ad was actually seen by users
questions.correctAnswer: Whether an ad was actually seen by users
questions.explanation: Viewability measures whether an ad was actually in a position where a user could see it, as opposed to just being loaded on the page.

questions.question: What is 'Invalid Traffic' (IVT)?
questions.correctAnswer: Bot traffic and fraud
questions.explanation: Invalid Traffic refers to impressions, clicks, or conversions generated by bots or other fraudulent sources rather than real human users.

questions.question: What is a 'Pixel' in tracking?
options: 1x1 transparent image used to track user activity
questions.correctAnswer: 1x1 transparent image used to track user activity
questions.explanation: A tracking pixel is a 1x1 transparent image loaded on a webpage that triggers a server request, allowing tracking of user behavior.

questions.question: What is 'SIVT'?
questions.correctAnswer: Sophisticated Invalid Traffic
questions.explanation: SIVT (Sophisticated Invalid Traffic) consists of more difficult to detect fraud mechanisms like hijacked devices or malware, requiring advanced analytics to identify.

questions.question: What defines a 'Bounce Rate'?
options: Users who return to the site
Percentage of visitors who navigate away after viewing only one page
questions.correctAnswer: Percentage of visitors who navigate away after viewing only one page
questions.explanation: Bounce Rate is the percentage of visitors who enter the site and then leave ('bounce') rather than continuing to view other pages.

questions.question: What is a 'UTM Parameter'?
options: Urchin Tracking Module tags added to URLs
questions.correctAnswer: Urchin Tracking Module tags added to URLs
questions.explanation: UTM parameters are tags added to the end of a URL to track the effectiveness of online marketing campaigns across traffic sources.

questions.question: What is 'Cross-Device Tracking'?
options: Identifying the same user across different devices
questions.correctAnswer: Identifying the same user across different devices
questions.explanation: Cross-device tracking identifies and links a user's activity across multiple devices (phone, laptop, tablet) to build a unified profile.

chapters.title: 7. Media-Buying
chapters.description: RTB, Auctions, Deal IDs, and Programmatic.

questions.question: What is Real-Time Bidding (RTB)?
questions.correctAnswer: Automated auction in milliseconds
questions.explanation: RTB is a technology where ad impressions are bought and sold via an instantaneous programmatic auction.

questions.question: What is 'Bid Shading'?
options: Optimizing bid price between first and second price
questions.correctAnswer: Optimizing bid price between first and second price
questions.explanation: Bid shading is an algorithm used to pay less than the highest bid in a first-price auction, approximating a second-price auction outcome.

questions.question: What is a 'First-Price Auction'?
options: Winner pays the second highest price
Winner pays exactly what they bid
questions.correctAnswer: Winner pays exactly what they bid
questions.explanation: In a first-price auction, the highest bidder wins and pays exactly the amount they bid.

questions.question: What is a 'Deal ID'?
options: A unique identifier for a programmatic deal
questions.correctAnswer: A unique identifier for a programmatic deal
questions.explanation: A Deal ID is a unique number assigned to an automated ad buy, allowing buyers and sellers to identify a specific package of inventory.

questions.question: What is an 'Ad Exchange'?
options: A platform facilitating buying/selling of impressions
questions.correctAnswer: A platform facilitating buying/selling of impressions
questions.explanation: An ad exchange is a technological platform that facilitates the buying and selling of ad impressions between advertisers and publishers.

questions.question: What is a 'Second-Price Auction'?
questions.correctAnswer: Winner pays second highest bid + $0.01
questions.explanation: In a second-price auction, the highest bidder wins but pays the amount bid by the second-highest bidder plus one cent.

questions.question: What is 'Floor Price'?
questions.correctAnswer: Lowest allowed bid price
questions.explanation: A floor price is the minimum price a publisher is willing to accept for their ad inventory in an auction.

questions.question: What is 'Programmatic Advertising'?
questions.correctAnswer: Automated buying/selling of ad inventory
questions.explanation: Programmatic advertising is the automated buying and selling of online advertising using technology and algorithms.

questions.question: What is 'Programmatic Direct'?
questions.correctAnswer: Automated buying of guaranteed inventory
questions.explanation: Programmatic Direct allows advertisers to buy guaranteed inventory directly from publishers via an automated interface, skipping the auction.

questions.question: What is 'PMP'?
questions.correctAnswer: Private Marketplace
questions.explanation: A Private Marketplace (PMP) is an invite-only auction where high-caliber publishers offer their premium inventory to a selected group of buyers.

chapters.title: 8. User Identification
chapters.description: Cookies, IDs, Privacy Sandbox, and Clean Rooms.

questions.question: What are 'Third-Party Cookies'?
options: Cookies set by the website you visit
Cookies set by domains other than the one you're visiting
questions.correctAnswer: Cookies set by domains other than the one you're visiting
questions.explanation: Third-party cookies are set by a domain other than the one the user is visiting, typically used for tracking and advertising purposes.

questions.question: What are 'First-Party Cookies'?
options: Cookies set by the website you're visiting
questions.correctAnswer: Cookies set by the website you're visiting
questions.explanation: First-party cookies are created and stored by the website domain that the user is directly visiting.

questions.question: What is a 'Universal ID'?
questions.correctAnswer: A cross-platform user identifier
questions.explanation: Universal IDs are identifier solutions designed to work across different websites and platforms, often as an alternative to third-party cookies.

questions.question: What is 'Fingerprinting' in AdTech?
options: Identifying users without cookies based on device/browser characteristics
questions.correctAnswer: Identifying users without cookies based on device/browser characteristics
questions.explanation: Fingerprinting is a method of identifying users by collecting characteristics about their device and browser configuration without using cookies.

questions.question: What is a 'Clean Room' in AdTech?
options: Secure environment for analyzing data without exposing raw data
questions.correctAnswer: Secure environment for analyzing data without exposing raw data
questions.explanation: Clean rooms are secure environments where different parties can analyze combined data without exposing their raw individual user data to each other.

questions.question: What is 'Privacy Sandbox'?
questions.correctAnswer: Google's initiative for privacy-preserving advertising
questions.explanation: Privacy Sandbox is Google's initiative to develop privacy-preserving alternatives to third-party cookies for online advertising.

questions.question: Which browser first blocked 3rd-party cookies by default?
questions.correctAnswer: Safari (ITP)
questions.explanation: Apple's Safari was the first major browser to block third-party cookies by default with its Intelligent Tracking Prevention (ITP).

questions.question: What is 'ITP'?
questions.correctAnswer: Intelligent Tracking Prevention
questions.explanation: ITP (Intelligent Tracking Prevention) is a feature in WebKit (Safari) that reduces cross-site tracking by limiting cookie usage.

questions.question: Which of these is a deterministic identifier?
questions.correctAnswer: Email Address (Hashed)
questions.explanation: Deterministic IDs are based on known user data like email addresses or login IDs, providing high accuracy for cross-device tracking.

questions.question: What is the main goal of Google's Topics API?
options: To replace cookies with interest-based cohorts
To track individual user history intimately
questions.correctAnswer: To replace cookies with interest-based cohorts
questions.explanation: Topics API assigns users broad interest categories based on browsing history without sharing specific sites visited with advertisers.

questions.question: What does a DMP mostly deal with?
questions.correctAnswer: Audience data management
questions.explanation: A DMP collects, stores, and organizes data from multiple sources to help with audience segmentation and targeting.

questions.question: What is 'Data Enrichment' in a DMP?
questions.correctAnswer: Enhancing data with additional attributes
questions.explanation: Data enrichment is the process of enhancing collected data with additional attributes and information from various sources to make it more valuable.

questions.question: What is 'First-Party Data'?
options: Data collected directly from your own audience
questions.correctAnswer: Data collected directly from your own audience
questions.explanation: First-party data is the information you collect directly from your audience or customers (e.g., website behavior, CRM data).

questions.question: What is 'Second-Party Data'?
options: Data stored on a second server
questions.correctAnswer: Someone else's First-Party Data
questions.explanation: Second-party data is essentially someone else's first-party data that you access directly from the source through a partnership.

questions.question: What is 'Third-Party Data'?
options: Data aggregated from various sources and sold by vendors
questions.correctAnswer: Data aggregated from various sources and sold by vendors
questions.explanation: Third-party data is data bought from outside sources (data aggregators) that are not the original collectors of that data.

questions.question: What is a 'Data Lake'?
options: A centralized repository for storing strictured and unstructured data
questions.correctAnswer: A centralized repository for storing strictured and unstructured data
questions.explanation: A data lake allows you to store all your data at any scale, including raw, unstructured data, unlike a data warehouse which stores structured data.

questions.question: Which represents a 'demographic' data segment?
options: Users who visited the site yesterday
questions.correctAnswer: Users aged 25-34
questions.explanation: Demographic segments classify audiences based on statistical characteristics like age, gender, income, and education.

questions.question: What is 'Lookback Window' in data attribution?
options: The time period before conversion to credit an ad impression
A feature to see past website versions
questions.correctAnswer: The time period before conversion to credit an ad impression
questions.explanation: A lookback window defines how far back in time from a conversion event the system should look to identifying contributing ad impressions or clicks.

questions.question: What is 'Zero-Party Data'?
options: Data a customer intentionally and proactively shares
questions.correctAnswer: Data a customer intentionally and proactively shares
questions.explanation: Zero-party data is data that a customer intentionally and proactively shares with a brand, like preferences, purchase intentions, and personal context.

questions.question: What is 'PII'?
questions.correctAnswer: Personally Identifiable Information
questions.explanation: PII (Personally Identifiable Information) refers to any data that can distinguish or trace an individual's identity, such as name, email, or social security number.

questions.question: What is 'Attribution'?
questions.correctAnswer: Assigning credit for a conversion
questions.explanation: Attribution is the science of assigning credit to marketing touchpoints that lead to a conversion.

questions.question: What is 'Last Click Attribution'?
questions.correctAnswer: Last touchpoint gets all credit
questions.explanation: In Last Click Attribution, 100% of the conversion credit is given to the last touchpoint before the conversion occurred.

questions.question: What is 'Linear Attribution'?
questions.correctAnswer: All touchpoints get equal credit
questions.explanation: In Linear Attribution, credit for a conversion is distributed equally across all touchpoints in the customer journey.

questions.question: What is 'Time Decay Attribution'?
questions.correctAnswer: Recent touchpoints get more credit
questions.explanation: In Time Decay Attribution, touchpoints closer to the conversion receive more credit than earlier ones in the customer journey.

questions.question: What is 'Position Based Attribution'?
options: First and last touchpoints get most credit
questions.correctAnswer: First and last touchpoints get most credit
questions.explanation: Position Based Attribution (also called U-shaped) gives 40% credit to first touch, 40% to last touch, and distributes remaining 20% among middle touchpoints.

questions.question: What is 'MTA' in measurement?
questions.correctAnswer: Multi-Touch Attribution
questions.explanation: Multi-Touch Attribution (MTA) is a measurement technique that evaluates the impact of each touchpoint across the consumer journey.

questions.question: What is an 'Attribution Window'?
options: The time period after an ad interaction during which a conversion is credited
questions.correctAnswer: The time period after an ad interaction during which a conversion is credited
questions.explanation: An attribution window (or lookback window) is the defined period of time after a user interacts with an ad for which a conversion will be attributed to that ad.

questions.question: What is 'Marketing Mix Modeling' (MMM)?
options: Statistical analysis to estimate the impact of various marketing tactics
questions.correctAnswer: Statistical analysis to estimate the impact of various marketing tactics
questions.explanation: MMM determines how various marketing drivers (like TV, digital, price, promotion) contribute to sales using historical aggregate data.

questions.question: What does 'Incremental Lift' measure?
options: The percentage of conversions that happened ONLY because of the ad
questions.correctAnswer: The percentage of conversions that happened ONLY because of the ad
questions.explanation: Incrementality measures the lift in desired outcomes (conversions) that occurred specifically as a result of the advertising campaign, excluding organic conversions.

questions.question: What is 'Algorithmic Attribution'?
options: Using machine learning to dynamically assign credit to touchpoints
questions.correctAnswer: Using machine learning to dynamically assign credit to touchpoints
questions.explanation: Algorithmic (or Data-Driven) attribution uses machine learning to analyze conversion paths and dynamically assign credit to touchpoints based on their actual statistical contribution.

questions.question: What is 'Remnant Inventory'?
questions.correctAnswer: Unsold inventory sold for less
questions.explanation: Remnant inventory is inventory that a publisher has been unable to sell directly and is often sold for a lower price via networks or exchanges.

questions.question: What is 'Frequency Capping'?
options: Limiting how often a user sees an ad
questions.correctAnswer: Limiting how often a user sees an ad
questions.explanation: Frequency capping limits the number of times a specific user sees a particular ad within a given time period.

questions.question: What is 'Premium Inventory'?
questions.correctAnswer: Most valuable publisher ad space
questions.explanation: Premium inventory is the publisher's most valuable space, typically found on well-known sites, high-traffic pages, or highly visible placements.

questions.question: What is 'AdOps'?
questions.correctAnswer: Ad Operations team
questions.explanation: AdOps refers to the people responsible for setting up ad campaigns, trafficking tags, and managing campaign execution.

questions.question: What is 'DCO'?
questions.correctAnswer: Dynamic Creative Optimization
questions.explanation: Dynamic Creative Optimization (DCO) is a process where advertisers show personalized ads to individual users based on information known about them.

questions.question: What is 'Budget Pacing'?
options: Spending budget as fast as possible
Distributing budget evenly over campaign duration
questions.correctAnswer: Distributing budget evenly over campaign duration
questions.explanation: Budget pacing (or distribution) is the strategy of spreading ad spend evenly across the campaign duration to avoid spending the entire budget too quickly.

questions.question: Why would a company build their own Ad Tech stack?
options: To have full control over data and customisation
questions.correctAnswer: To have full control over data and customisation
questions.explanation: Companies build their own stack (in-housing) to gain transparency, control over proprietary data, and customization that off-the-shelf solutions can't provide.

questions.question: What is a 'Media Plan'?
options: A document detailing the strategy, budget, and placement of ads
questions.correctAnswer: A document detailing the strategy, budget, and placement of ads
questions.explanation: A Media Plan is a comprehensive guide to a campaign's advertising efforts, including audience targeting, channels, budget allocation, and timing.

questions.question: What represents the 'Ad Tech Tax'?
options: Fees taken by intermediaries in the supply chain
questions.correctAnswer: Fees taken by intermediaries in the supply chain
questions.explanation: The 'Ad Tech Tax' refers to the portion of an advertiser's budget that is absorbed by fees from DSPs, exchanges, SSPs, and data providers before reaching the publisher.

questions.question: What is a 'Unified Auction'?
options: An auction where all demand sources compete simultaneously
questions.correctAnswer: An auction where all demand sources compete simultaneously
questions.explanation: A unified auction allows all demand sources (header bidding, direct, exchange) to bid on inventory at the same time, maximizing yield compared to a waterfall.
